We will target followers of popular accounts in your niche. We will engage with the most engaged users by following them and liking their most recent posts on their accounts, and by doing so attracting attention to your account.
More followers =
* More exposure for your business, increase sales; Reach highly targeted customers for your business who will convert into clients, leads and sales!

* Increase sales and brand awareness; Your business, your name, your account will be seen by thousands of people a day. Exposing potential buyers to your brand again and again is part of the consumer journey.
Our most popular plan starts at 69 USD per month, for which you will get around 1000+ targeted followers each month.
We have a $1 1 week trial: https://socialchief.co/get-started/
If you have any questions, please let me know. You can contact me at dimitri@socialcief.co or with the chat on the website. I'm looking forward to hearing from you!

item.title: Sample Page
item.dc:creator: admin
item.content:encoded:
This is an example page. It's different from a blog post because it will stay in one place and will show up in your site navigation (in most themes). Most people start with an About page that introduces them to potential site visitors. It might say something like this:
Hi there! I'm a bike messenger by day, aspiring actor by night, and this is my website. I live in Los Angeles, have a great dog named Jack, and I like piña coladas. (And gettin' caught in the rain.)
...or something like this:
The XYZ Doohickey Company was founded in 1971, and has been providing quality doohickeys to the public ever since. Located in Gotham City, XYZ employs over 2,000 people and does all kinds of awesome things for the Gotham community.
As a new WordPress user, you should go to your dashboard to delete this page and create new pages for your content. Have fun!

item.title: What's this all about....
item.dc:creator: admin
item.content:encoded:
Hello! Welcome to Mountain Biking Explained - a blog where I tackle some of the questions people have about mountain biking. This includes terminology, gear and tech, reviews and advice to help you get into mountain biking or get in a little deeper. I am certainly not the world's foremost expert on any of these items, but I do have a passion for mountain biking and a desire to learn and share with others as I go.
"What can I expect..."
My goal right now is to publish 2-3 well put together posts in one of the above areas each week. I also plan to add at least 2 videos per month to my youtube channel (which you can access from my homepage.) These videos will mostly be supplementary material for the posts on this blog, but may occasionally introduce entirely new material. I sincerely hope to create consistent and professional quality material in this endeavor. Most of the blog entries will be short form (1-2 paragraphs) and the videos will be around 7-10 minutes. As things progress I plan to devote more time to this and increase content quality and volume. For now, please check back a couple times a week to get inspired and informed about all things mountain biking.

item.title: Did I lube my chain with muddy water???
item.dc:creator: admin
item.content:encoded:
Few maintenance items are as important to do regularly as drivetrain cleaning and lubrication. Unfortunately the many different types of solvents and lubes can cause confusion and make cyclists less likely to do routine maintenance like this on their bikes. Wet, dry, semi-dry, PTFE, wax, spray, drip, etc - which one should I choose? Let's look at the basics of what to do and which products to use.

Conditions & Climate:

Weather and trail material plays a big part in choosing the proper lube for your ride. "Dry lube" is a double entendre of sorts, as it is made with a solvent and wax that allows the wax to be applied without melting it. It then "dries" (not really totally dry) and is therefore called "dry lube." On the other hand it is helpful to remember that "dry" lube is better for dry conditions so that dirt doesn't stick in the drivetrain as heavily. No one needs mudsauce in their jockey wheels. Unfortunately dry lube does not totally eliminate the problem of dusty dry trails, nor does it last as long or provide as much lubrication in my opinion as a wet lube. If you live in an area with dry dusty trails, it's best to clean and lubricate often-- check it every ride.

So called "wet" lubes are basically oil (at least that's my understanding) and are specced to various viscosities by different manufacturers. Typically they are heavier duty and less likely to be washed off by rain, puddles, dog urine😉 etc. They are thicker, thereby offering more lubrication and more ability to collect crap off the trail and literally grind your gears. If you commute on the road in the rain, wet lube is definitely for you. Otherwise many people tend to save it for winter or rainy times when the trails are not exactly dry.

 

Riding Style and Frequency:

If you ride three miles per week on a greenway or park path, you can probably get away with being lax on your drivetrain maintenance. I would stick with a wet lube and just lube it whenever you get the bike out. If you ride 20-30 miles per day on the trail, you probably already have a ritual cleansing that you do after every ride. It is likely that a dry lube will serve you better on the trails as long as you do it regularly. Supposedly with dry lubes it's better to lube after the ride (After cleaning the dirt off of course.) This allows some time for the lube to sit before you ride again, letting the solvent dry and leaving the waxy, teflon lube behind. Otherwise you'll sling some of the lubricant off the chain and onto your legs when you ride.

Whatever you choose to lubricate with, the most important concept is consistency. A good Sram or Shimano bike chain is like 20 bucks. An 11 speed cassette is like 50-80 bucks minimum, and the higher level groupset have exponentially more expensive cassettes. If you don't maintain your chain, it will wear out much more quickly, and you probably won’t notice that you're grinding the teeth off your cassette and chainring until its too late. Invest in a can of WD-40 and a toothbrush if you can’t afford the chain cleaning kits from Park or Finish Line (Finishline's is like 20 bucks on amazon) and clean your chain after every ride. After you clean it, lube it. This will allow you the luxury of just jumping on the bike the next chance you get to ride.

My "Best" Practices:

I use a degreaser (simple green) and a plastic lug nut brush -for cleaning car wheels with recessed lug-holes- to clean the drivetrain after (almost) every ride. I rinse the drivetrain lightly with a water hose, bounce it dry, and use a wax based dry lube daily for most of the year. I became a little more fanatical about this after upgrading to my current bike and getting halfway down a trail (several miles) and having shifting issues due to buildup in the chain and jockey wheels. I was on a 3 day trip, riding 15 plus miles per day in dry dusty conditions and thought I could make it without a good cleaning and re-lubing. Had to wipe what I could out of the jockey wheels with my fingers and limp it back to camp. My bike has the new NX groupset, so definitely not high-end, but it does shift a lot better now that I keep it clean. Happy Trails and Lucky Bails my friends.

item.title: New Video
item.dc:creator: admin
item.content:encoded:
I recently went to the trail with my friend Anthony and his new contraption. It's a PVC spider catcher that seems to work well. Visit my YouTube page to see my most recent video about spiders on the trail and how to avoid them.
https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=rsywWobRNrI

item.title: Heading to Bentonville AR
item.dc:creator: admin
item.content:encoded: I've been to the home of Walmart's headquarters several times now, and it does not disappoint a mountain bike enthusiast. From the trails at Slaughter Pen, to the dirt jumps at the Railyard, there is something for every skill level. Many of the trails are challenging even for experienced riders. If you want to go sometime and have limited time to ride, I recommend taking the seed tick shuffle to tatamagouche, then to Medusa, ending where you started after completing "The Downhill." This is a good overview of what Slaughter Pen has to offer. Seed tick is really more a connector than a real trail, but it takes you past a Free ride park and has some options for skinnies and drops if you want to warm up. After that, I'd recommend hitting the other side of Slaughter Pen toward downtown Bentonville. Depending on where you start, the order might be different, but be sure to ride All American, Urban Trail, Boo Boo, and Choo Choo. All of that could easily be done in a few hours and it will leave you smiling from ear to ear. I'll be out there again this weekend to ride as much as I can. It's a long drive but it's always worth it.

item.title: Tubeless-- Should I do it?
item.dc:creator: admin
item.content:encoded:
Everyone that has been into mountain biking for more than a few weeks has heard about "going tubeless." If you haven't heard, converting to "tubeless" is accomplished by 1. Removing the tubes from your tires, 2. Replacing the rim strip with a tubeless tape product or custom fitted tubeless rim strip to block off the holes in your wheel from the spoke nipples. 3. Adding tubeless valves to your wheel where the old tube valve used to go. 4. Adding sealant (Stan's, orange, slime even makes a tubeless sealant lol) 5. Seating the bead and inflating the tire. So, sounds pretty simple right? Especially if you have a TCS or tubeless compatible wheel and tire set. Some wheels come already taped as well. Unfortunately its not always as easy as it sounds. Last weekend, my friend Jonathan and I decided to convert our new(ish) bikes to tubeless. I have the Diamondback Blanchard 27.5 wheels with Schwalbe Hans Dampf tires--both tubeless compatible. Jon has Bontrager XR3 tires on his Bontrager Duster Wheels. He opted for the custom rubber rim strips, while I left mine as they came since they were already taped. Both of us had a really hard time getting the tires back on the rim - even with good tire levers- not a problem you want to have trailside. Once we fitted Jonathan's tire back to the rim (several tries and tire lever teamwork), we were able to seat the tire on the bead with an air compressor. It took almost 60 psi to get the bead to "pop" which was scary for the person holding the wheel. Once seated, we deflated Jon's tire and added sealant by removing the valve core and using a special bottle that added a pre-measured amount of tubeless sealant (about 4 oz per tire). We then re-installed the core and re-inflated the tire to proper pressure and spun the tire around to distribute the sealant. Something we learned through trial and error was that proper orientation of Bontrager tubeless valves is important to keep the bead from rolling instead of seating. For my wheels, the tire was a little easier to get back on after removing the tube, but not much. Seating the bead was a different story. My wheels were taped very tightly with thin, purpose specific rim tape. This left little "divots" where each of the holes for the spokes were in the rim. The tire was leaking air past the tire bead at each of these divots, so even with an air compressor, that bead would not seat. We had to add sealant and then one of us inflated while the other pulled the bead toward the rim while getting sprayed with stinky sealant residue. Finally after trying for a while we got the bead to pop on. I added sealant and re-inflated following the time tested spin the wheel and shake method to distribute sealant. Next morning the tire was about 1 psi. I realized that most of the sealant had escaped when trying to seat the bead, so I added more which solved the problem. So, after all that, would I recommend going tubeless? The answer is still yes. A tubeless setup offers many benefits that are not cancelled out by the initial difficulty and the trailside service issues.
  • Going tubeless virtually eliminates pinch flatting since there is no tube to pinch flat. Be careful with extremely low tire pressures as the sidewall of the tire can be cut by pinching it between the rim and a rock.
  • Lower pressure generally means more grip. You can afford lower pressure with a tubeless setup.
  • Removing tubes generally nets a decent weight savings even with the added weight of sealant.
  • If your pressure is a reasonable level for your tire size, your risk of sidewall tears is relatively low on well travelled trails. Watch out for sharp rocks and thorns.
  • Most punctures will be filled by the sealant. Even a tiny puncture with a tube will require a pitstop.
  • Modern tires will be difficult to remove and install on the trail whether you use tubes or not. At least with tubeless sealant, only a tire ripper will stop you.
If your wheels and tires are not tubeless ready, I would just leave them with tubes as its so easy to remove and reinstall the tires. This may not be the case for everybody in that boat, but for the everyday singletrack rider, just carry an extra tube or two. I have done the "ghetto tubeless conversion" using gorilla tape, as well as the small tube method. It isn't hard to do if you look up a tutorial on youtube, but I had a lot of sealant burp on the first few rides. What do you guys think? What setup are you running day to day? Was tubeless conversion harder than you expected? Let me know in the comments section.

item.title: Patron Ride with Seth's Bike Hacks
item.dc:creator: admin
item.content:encoded: I literally just got off the trail and am writing this on my phone from the seat of my car. What a great day. I got to meet a lot of cool people who ride hard, as well as one of the YouTube mountain bike scene's biggest success stories, Seth from Seth's Bike Hacks. We started off riding a couple laps of flow trail at Slaughter Pen called "The Downhill." Afterwards Seth took the time to let everyone get a picture with him and handed out loads of prototype stickers. Also, in an unusual and unexpected turn of events, we got to meet Drama, everyone's favorite trail dog. We continued on riding several iconic trails and ended up downtown for a late lunch at Peddler's pub. The food and company were excellent and everyone who was left got to have a dinner table Q & A with Seth. After stuffing our faces we ended the day saying farewell to Seth at the Crystal Bridges Art gallery, after which a few of us rode another 5 miles back to the main parking lot, of course hitting a few more trails on the way. Today exceeded my expectations in every way, from how Seth ran the ride keeping it fun during the breaks, and not losing anyone that wanted to keep going, to the trails themselves- well crafted and very rideable for many different skill levels. Even the weather was great. Other than a bent derailleur hanger and some saddle soreness, no major injuries to report. I hope to catch up with all these cool people again sometime if Seth does another patron Ride.

item.title: Berryman Trail
item.dc:creator: admin
item.content:encoded:
25 miles of singletrack.
+-4000ft elevation change.
105 heat index.
162 racers.
6 hours later....we finished.

item.title: Learning to Jump Part 2
item.dc:creator: admin
item.content:encoded:
I just uploaded a new video to my youtube channel chronicling the next chapter in my skills development. I plan to build some medium sized jumps so I can practice locally and actually clear them when I visit cool trails. This clip was from a Patron Ride with Seth's Bike Hacks recently in Bentonville, AR. I am working on a full cut from the day featuring the trails and people on the ride. Look for that sometime next week.
 
For now, give this a look:
https://youtu.be/XwUAWYrgZa4

item.title: XFusion Manic Dropper Post Review
item.dc:creator: admin
item.content:encoded: The Xfusion Manic has been out for a while now, but unfiltered and unbiased reviews still aren't really out there. I'll be honest- I have never owned a high end dropper like the Rockshox Reverb or the Thompson Elite. I've demoed a KS Lev and Giant's branded dropper, but most of my experience has been with budget posts like the RSP plummet and the KS eTen. I purchased the Manic after reading about it in Mountain Bike Action and was excited to get some higher end features at the sub $200 price point. First of all, I have to say that availability has been an issue. I originally ordered the post from a popular website that I will not name. Let's call them KensonUSA.com. When I ordered I was informed that the product would not be available for 3 weeks due to shortage of stock. As I was able to use a discount code to further drive down the price this was not a deal-breaker for me. However, after 3 weeks, I called to inquire about the order and was given a really crappy answer of "Uhh, Xfusion had a problem and it will be like three more weeks." I did a little searching and found it elsewhere for the retail price and had the post at my house from Ireland in less than a week. I let you guess what site that was. Once the post arrived, I was impressed at the care taken by Xfusion to package the post to ensure safe shipping. The box had camera case style foam padding with cutouts for the parts. It included everything I needed to put the post in the bike except tools. On the other hand, the instructions were less than helpful. And youtube failed me miserably. Searching for installation videos kept showing the hilo, which is different. I opted to just figure it out as I went. One tip if you've never installed an internally routed dropper is to leave yourself a little more housing than you think you need- maybe an inch or two. It's easier to cut it down after than to find a new housing. I installed the button where I wanted it, turned the handlebars all the way to the stop on the left, wrapped the cable around the right side of the frame, down and then up through the seat tube. My bike is a Diamondback Release 1. I measured the cable and housing to where the bottom of the post would be at the highest it would ever be in the seat tube. I then removed the lever from the bars to allow me to attach the cable to the post by pulling the cable out through the seat tube without leaving the cable to long. Now, on to the ergonomics and design. One of the main reasons I bought the Manic over the RSP plummet stealth was the actuation lever. The manic comes with a shifter-style lever that has an adjustment for the angle that your thumb hits it. I love this design and think it should be standard on all dropper posts because the stock lever for KS and RSP sucks. It also has a barrel adjuster for getting the tension just right. Just like with your derailleur, most of the adjustment should be done at the dropper post, but its nice to have a fine adjustment that doesn't require any tools or a fourth hand. The post itself is a two bolt design which is a big upgrade over the single bolt seat clamp on the KS eTen. The second bolt makes the seat more secure and allows you to move your seat farther forward or back to get the most comfortable position over your pedals. My biggest gripe in the design is the insertion length. I have a medium frame with no bottle cage holes in the seat tube and I cannot get the 125mm version all the way in. I think this is ridiculous, and I know it's not a problem with either the KS Lev or the eTen. I have to leave about 3" of the post up when I have it slammed all the way down which sucks. The KS Lev has a 215mm insertion length in 31.6mm size, while the Manic has a 247mm insertion length. 32 mils is a big difference when you compare them side by side. Aside from that, the Manic is freakin' heavy! Almost 200 grams more than the Lev. With all of the previous in mind, how does this post perform for the price? Meh. The actuation is noticeably better the KS eTen, but its not up to the level of higher end posts. It's fairly smooth, but is slow and has no adjustment for the speed of the return. This is not a big deal to me because I don't want the post to rocket up toward my soft parts anyway, but some people want a fast post. Make sure you don't over tighten the seat post clamp as this post is very sensitive and over-tightening will cause the post to stick on the return. I will say that the post is very stable, and has very little play side to side. The air and oil in the post are separated utilizing a replaceable cartridge, which eliminates the problems that plague some cheaper posts (suspension feeling, post pulling up without using the lever, etc). Overall, the post is acceptable. There are significant compromises in weight and adjustability, and the insertion length is ridiculous. But, keep in mind that this post barely costs more than the cheapest posts. It's almost half the price of the KS Lev and less than half of the Rockshox Reverb or the Thompson Elite. The post performs significantly better than the bottom end posts on the market, and the lever design is fantastic. If cost is what is holding you back from a dropper post upgrade, the Xfusion Manic could be the solution for you as it was for me. I don't think this will be anyones favorite post, but if you aren't counting grams and you have a tall seat tube, you can't beat the value. Was this review helpful? Do you want me to do a video review or an installation tutorial?Are there better posts out there for the money that perform better? Is this post durable long term? Let me know in the comments!

item.title: Cycling hit and run
item.dc:creator: admin
item.content:encoded: An aquaintance of mine in the cycling community was involved in a hit and run accident. The driver mowed into him from behind at high speed and continued on as if nothing happened. He is severely injured and will have a long recovery but is expected to remain in stable condition. Please visit the GoFundMe page that has been set up to help cover the family's medical expenses and follow the story on KFVS 12 to assist in searching for the perpetrator of this senseless crime. The link is below and the artical can be easily found by googling "Jason Summers KFVS 12". I would share the link to the article but it redirects to the news sites homepage.  https://www.gofundme.com/jasons-cycling-accident

item.title: 2017 Diamondback Release 1 Review
item.dc:creator: admin
item.content:encoded:
When a person gets into mountain biking for the first time, they generally follow a prescribed path.
First they get a walmart bike, or maybe a budget hardtail. Some people shop used, some buy online, some get a deal on Craigslist or pink bike. Usually though, they end up with a very basic bike that they outgrow quickly.
Then they start looking for a full squish. Here the options are endless. If you're like me, this purchase is going to be significant to your budget, so you want to squeeze every ounce of performance out of the dollars you're forking out. So we research the crap out of it- looking for the absolute best components, warranty, looks, and reputation for the least money. We look for the deal that no one else sees so we don't feel ripped off. Let's be honest- 1 to 3k is a crazy amount to spend on a bike and we don't want to get buyers remorse when they see that sweeter deal next week.
I found myself in this stereotypical scenario when I went for my first full-suspension rig recently. After comparing bikes for months from the big 3 and boutique brands, I had narrowed it down to a few winners, when I decided to take another look at Diamondback on the recommendation of someone I really respect in the cycling community. I had considered DB in the past when I was at a lower price point, but decided to hold off on purchasing an entry-level full suspension and waited until I could go for a top-tier bike with a 1x drivetrain and a more sophisticated rear linkage over the single-pivot style that you find in the sub 1500 dollar range.
So, now that you know whether or not this review will be helpful to you, I will tell you why I bought the DB Release 1 over the other bikes I was considering and whether or not I think the grass is greener on the other side.
Price. At the time of my purchase, the diamondback was on sale for 25 percent off, from 2500 to 2000. On top of that, I was given an opportunity to take advantage of another discount available to certain corporations. Contact Diamondback for details as to whether or not you qualify. In the 2500 dollar price point, you can get a high end aluminum full sus bike from many brands, and they are all specced pretty well the same, the main variables being your preference of Shimano or Sram, and setup preferences such as geometry and such. So, as it were, my main reason for going with then diamondback brand was that they were the cheapest available to me that met all my needs.
At my price point of 2-3k, I had some expectations that I would not compromise on. My main concern was a multi pivot suspension, because the frame is one thing you can never really upgrade (I plan to keep this bike and upgrade stuff along the way). My second expectation was that I would get a 1x drivetrain. Sram's NX groupset is about the cheapest option for a 1x11, in spite of that, I was confident that it would meet my needs. One thing I expected to get that I compromised on was an included dropper post. Because of my significant discount, I opted to pick one up separately rather than upgrade to the Release 2 or another bike brand that includes one. I wanted at least 130 mil travel in the front, but no more than 160 (Release has 150). I wanted a slack headtube, but not a crazy angle (still gotta climb) I believe the Release has a 66 deg headtube angle. It climbs like a mountain goat with the 30 tooth chainring and 11-42 cassette. I was also looking for a snappy rear end with shorter chain stays. The diamondback fits the bill with a shorter reach to boot compared to my hardtail. This geometry, combined with the 27.5 wheels, makes for a playful bike that is easy to pop a wheelie on.
I was hesitant to go with a direct to consumer brand primarily because of customer service after the sale. This is an area that Diamondback really shines that you might not be expecting from a business model that attracts consumers with low prices and free shipping. But you will be surprised. I found it is better to call if you have an issue or question as hold times were almost nonexistent. When I emailed the response time was usually about 24 hours (which is actually pretty standard). Diamondback really stands out with their attitude toward the customer. You definitely feel that they are there to help you, and that your issue or question is important to them. They also offer a good return policy if you decide that the bike isn't going to work for you. They include some extras in with some of the bikes, which is good because you will be doing the final bit of assembly yourself. I received a shock pump, a tool kit with a torque wrench, pedals, and an extra derailleur hanger. The bike was lovingly packaged with thick foam and velcro straps instead of zip ties, so you don't have to put a knife to your new frame. The bike was tuned up to the point that I literally just put the handlebars on, set the sag, added air to the tires and started riding.
Now on to the good stuff. How does it ride? This was my first 650b bike, my first full suspension, and my first diamondback. I am very impressed and prefer each of these things over what I've had in the past. The bike feels plush with the Yari fork dialed in, the linkage in the rear virtually eliminates pedal bob (i did have to add 4 volume reducers to the shock to keep from bottoming out.) I'm not a speed demon so I've not felt I needed a larger chainring yet, and the low-end is challenging on big climbs, but gives you just enough to power through. I like the short stem and wide bars, but I think I may shave them down to 760mm for more clearance and upright posture. I'm 5' 9" on a medium frame.
I have been pleased with the setup and durability of the bike overall. So now my gripes:
The seat is not very comfortable. Of course I can swap it out, but they aren't cheap. For now it will do. I just have to wear chamois on long rides.
When setting up the wheels for tubeless, the pre-installed Rim tape leaves divots over the spoke holes, which makes seating the tire bead difficult to due to air leaking past- even with a compressor.
The included Kraton locking grips are not very durable (or comfortable) and they are about half worn out after only 100 miles.
Diamondback's choice of the NX level groupset seems like cheaping out at this price point. I would rather have seen GX or Shimano SLX for weight savings alone. The amount of money saved is small when compared to how expensive it is to re-buy a groupset even just one level up. The weight of the NX cassette is just silly compared to similar offerings.
A dropper post is not included on a 2500 dollar msrp bike? What??!! Well, the fork is a higher level than most comparable bikes from other brands that include a dropper, so you win some you lose some. Giant includes a dropper with it's Trance 3 at 2300 bucks, but has a Suntour Aion fork and only a 1x10 drivetrain.
Ultimately, I find that this bike is well equipped without significant upgrading, and would highly recommend this bike when it's on sale, or if you can get the discount that I received. Otherwise, you may wish to make some tradeoffs and go with the Giant Trance 2 (300 dollars more at $2825 for the 2018 model) or a similar offering from another brand.
edit: The Release Carbon has just been "released" and the prices are on fire right now for the aluminum versions! You can snag a Release 1 for 1749 without any discount, and a top-level Release 3 for 2499 if you need the x01, dropper, and pike fork. In my opinion, these price reductions make DB the best value trail bike dollar for dollar.

item.title: New posts coming soon!
item.dc:creator: admin
item.content:encoded: My apologies for the radio silence this past week. I have been editing video from my last trip to Bentonville and working on an in-depth 1 month review of the 2017 Diamondback Release 1. Both should be ready this week, so please stay tuned.

item.title: Improving Mountain Bike Fitness
item.dc:creator: admin
item.content:encoded: I started cycling again to lose weight and get healthier. Then, at some point, I began getting healthier and losing weight to cycle better and more often. Ironic. Recently I made a decision to improve my cardiovascular fitness. I find that on extended climbs, or even somewhat short steep climbs, I'm dying at the top and have to rest, or worse, get off and walk the bike up the rest of the hill. Now, I will say that this doesn't happen on my normal rides, just when I go to a place that tests my limits. Ive been monitoring my heart rate during my rides, and find that I average about 129 bpm on my usual trails at about a 10 mph pace. Not too bad for me, but these trails are relatively minor in elevation change. My favorite trail has something like 900ft elevation change in 12 miles. When I go somewhere more challenging (especially technical, loose climbs) I begin to struggle. One option would be to just ride harder every time on my local trails to improve my fitness, but to me, being absolutely exhausted after every ride takes the fun out of it in the long term. My other option- become a biathlete. Ugh. I hate running. But, just as I lost weight and improved my diet to cycle more effectively, I will trudge on. Immediately I noticed that, although my cycling muscle groups have strengthened to the point I can go on a "long" ride without soreness (25mi or so) I was sore for a couple days after running just 2 miles! Also, my running times are just as bad as they ever were. The other thing I noticed was that even at my crappy pace, My average heart rate was about 160, which is much more in line with building cardiovascular strength, takes less time than a long ride, and doesn't ruin mountain biking for me. I will keep you updated on my fitness journey, and will post my before and after numbers in a few weeks when I re-test my cycling cardio on a hill that killed me in Bentonville. My goal is to be able to dominate the climb to "The Downhill" without going into peak HR zones or hiking my bike.

item.title: Biking With Seth's Bike Hacks
item.dc:creator: admin
item.content:encoded:
I'm finally uploading the video from Seth's recent patron ride in Bentonville, AR. Please take the time to visit my YouTube channel by clicking the "Check out my latest Video" button on the homepage. It should be finished uploading by tomorrow morning (10/17/17). Be sure to leave a comment about what you'd like to see in future videos, what you liked, or even what you hated about the video. Thanks!
Here's the link now that its up:
https://youtu.be/3xCINRElWSU

item.title: Cyclists with Small Children
item.dc:creator: admin
item.content:encoded: I would assume that most cyclists who have children want their children to enjoy cycling as well, and do their best to involve them in the activity. From a very early age (probably 4 or 5 on average) children are capable of riding without training wheels if they have the opportunity to practice. I have seen videos of children this small even beginning to ride off-road on teeny little mountain bikes. And don't worry, the bike manufacturers have noticed this and developed bikes for children that cost as much as adult bikes. I say all this to get to a point- what about the rest of us? I mean in particular those who have children not yet old enough to ride a bike of their own. The trail-a-bike system won't work safely for an 18 month old. I would also have serious qualms about hitting a trail with one of those seat-post car seat things. What happens if you wreck? Will those things even mount to a dropper? Then you have the little axle-mount trailers. I actually own one of these. They don't work with modern through-axles, they have very little ground clearance, are very heavy, and lack any suspension. Doesn't sound like a good idea for the trail either. I guess many times a parent of a small child just stops biking for a few years. If your spouse doesn't cycle with you, you could take turns watching the child, or you can hire a sitter for a bike date. In any case having a toddler makes it a lot harder to get out to the trails. I had a dream the other night of the perfect solution- a mountain bike specific bike trailer. This trailer would be constructed of thin, tubular aluminum in a spherical shape. The bottom would be a resin bowl with a seat and 5-point adjustable harness. The real difference would be the shape and wheel orientation- one wheel, or even better a tandem axle with the wheels in-line. This would allow for a trailer style suspension, as well as superior cornering and trailside clearance. The wheels would be ultralight aluminum with replaceable tubed tires. The mounting system would be optimized for through-axles, with a different end for more traditional trailer mount capability. I have included a mock up of my trailer design as the featured image. Have you ever seen anything like this? Can anyone make these please? Let me know in the comments below. We really need a solution that works.

item.title: Your First Bike - Hydraulic Disk Brakes?
item.dc:creator: admin
item.content:encoded:
When you purchase your first "real" mountain bike, a lot of the time people come up with a list of important features and then shop around to find the best deal. This was true for me, and one of the features I spent a little more for (about $100) was hydraulic disk brakes. I had read that hydraulic brakes outperform mechanical especially in wet conditions. That may sound like an obvious advantage for hydraulic, but it has some hidden caveats. First of all, just like everything else, there is "entry level" and "performance" when it comes to hydraulic disk brake components. When you compare a high end or even mid-grade hydraulic disk to a mechanical, there is definitely more stopping power and less noticeable decrease in performance when components get wet or hot. However, cheap hydraulic brakes, such as the "Tektro Draco" found on my first hardtail, leave users questioning why you would ever want a hydraulic disk brake system.
The Dracos are heavier than their mechanical brethren, have absolutely ZERO modulation, are more difficult to adjust, and then you have to get a special bleed kit to bleed them at least every season, if not every 100 miles or so. I found myself working on the brakes every few rides, and the lack of modulation really held me back while learning to wheelie. The simplicity of a mechanical brake setup on the other hand, makes them the choice for many bike-packers and roadies, and they have plenty of stopping power for anything but downhill bike parks and some downhill oriented single-track that you might find in Colorado or North Carolina. I'm not saying that no one should use hydraulic disk brakes, just that the cheap ones suck, and mechanicals will help your dollar go farther on the other bike components you are looking for in your first bike. If I had saved that 100 dollars, I could have spent it on better pedals and grips--something that would have been a huge improvement right off the bat. Once you get into a higher price point, you can get Shimano XTRs or Sram Guides (Or excellent brakes from other companies like Hope). It's just worth waiting for a good hydraulic brake that you won't be maintaining constantly.
If you would be interested in a video on the cheapest way to bleed the crappy hydraulic brakes that you already bought, let me know. It is absolutely necessary on those Dracos and can make them usable again if you have put some miles on them and still need them to work!

item.title: The Future of this Blog...
item.dc:creator: admin
item.content:encoded: Time for some housekeeping around here. I am going to continue writing this blog as long as I feel there is something I can add to the mountain biking community, which will hopefully be indefinitely. However, at this time I am not able to keep up three interesting and well-formed posts per week. I am currently back in school and continue to work and have a family life, (and of course ride!) so for the next few months, I will be writing about once per week as I have time and something to say. I appreciate any feedback you may give and will return to three posts per week when I finish school in the summer of 2018. Until then, continue to send me ideas and comments- if I don't get to them now, I will have a stockpile to write about when I graduate. Thanks Ryan

item.title: Night Rider
item.dc:creator: admin
item.content:encoded:
Well, it's getting dark in the Midwest at about 4:30 CST these days. What is a mountain biker to do? I guess some people will go at lunch, but I like my ride to be uninterrupted by my schedule. I want the freedom to do another lap or go the long way around. I want to session that area that I can't clear, or that sweet bump-jump that I found. I need to ride after work is over. That pretty much just leaves night riding. I'm working on a setup to light up the woods like daylight with bar mounted floodlights and a helmet spot light. I know that companies like Sigma make sweet setups that run on battery packs and light up a airplane runway, but come on- 300 dollars for a flashlight? I'll be jerryrigging my setup for around 40 bucks. 
I'm sure there will be plenty of falls, and it will probably be a little spooky out there by myself, but I think it could be a really fun way to refresh myself on the bike. Between school and the shorter days I have only been on the bike a handful of times in the past few weeks, so I have to find a new way to make it work with my schedule. If you have any tips and tricks for beating the winter blues or specificly night riding, leave a comment below.

item.title: Winter Training
item.dc:creator: admin
item.content:encoded: Did anybody else hate winter? I tried to use a trainer, but it's just not the same and Zwift was quite disappointing after about 5 minutes. It's been nice to have some good enough weather to get back on the trails. In the next few weeks I will be finishing up school, and returning to posting regularly on this blog. My plan for this summer is to start reviewing and providing detailed information on the trails I visit. I will be providing trail maps, ratings, and difficulty levels for each available trail in each system that I visit. I'll probably start with my local trails, then branch out from there. For some reason Singletracks.com is kind of bare in my area, so I will try to be detailed and thorough.

item.title: Site is moving
item.dc:creator: admin
item.content:encoded: Don't worry, the address will stay the same, but I've been working on a new website and hope to have it up soon. Moving away from my current host and the wordpress scene. The new site will be simpler and customized to my needs, and eventually include my strava integration that allows tracking of individual parts on your bike.
